text: If you are writing a bunch of GraphQL queries in Julia, these tools I just published should be a big workflow improvement! <https://lauriumlabs.com/blog/julia-code-generation-with-graphql>

elements.text: If you are writing a bunch of GraphQL queries in Julia, these tools I just published should be a big workflow improvement!

text: cool I have a full fledged parser and generator that works quite well. I haven't made it public yet but maybe we can colab on this

elements.text: cool I have a full fledged parser and generator that works quite well. I haven't made it public yet but maybe we can colab on this

text: Definitely! I just started with the apollo-tooling generator which is in TypeScript and did major surgery on it... the workflow of using generated types from GraphQL queries is so cool

elements.text: Definitely! I just started with the apollo-tooling generator which is in TypeScript and did major surgery on it... the workflow of using generated types from GraphQL queries is so cool

text: I'm using RBNF.jl as the parser, once you get the hang of the API it's pretty easy to use

elements.text: I'm using RBNF.jl as the parser, once you get the hang of the API it's pretty easy to use

text: I'm got things working for the most part I just have to add more tests and do some cleanup

elements.text: I'm got things working for the most part I just have to add more tests and do some cleanup

text: Btw don't the Beacon Biosignals folks use GraphQL for stuff or did I misread that somewhere

root.text: If you are writing a bunch of GraphQL queries in Julia, these tools I just published should be a big workflow improvement! <https://lauriumlabs.com/blog/julia-code-generation-with-graphql>

elements.text: If you are writing a bunch of GraphQL queries in Julia, these tools I just published should be a big workflow improvement!
Btw don't the Beacon Biosignals folks use GraphQL for stuff or did I misread that somewhere

text: We do, but not from Julia currently (AFAIK, at least)

elements.text: We do, but not from Julia currently (AFAIK, at least)

text: Ok, yeah it would be great to use pure Julia, but parsers and AST are not my strength, so I just morphed an existing project until it worked. I have done 3 major projects using GraphQL and Code Generation (with <https://www.graphile.org/postgraphile/> providing the GraphQL api) and I cannot stress enough how productive the workflow is compared to REST

attachments.title: Graphile | Powerful, Extensible and Performant GraphQL APIs Rapidly
attachments.text: Utilities to build powerful, performant and extensible GraphQL APIs rapidly
attachments.fallback: Graphile | Powerful, Extensible and Performant GraphQL APIs Rapidly

elements.text: Ok, yeah it would be great to use pure Julia, but parsers and AST are not my strength, so I just morphed an existing project until it worked. I have done 3 major projects using GraphQL and Code Generation (with
providing the GraphQL api) and I cannot stress enough how productive the workflow is compared to REST

text:
> We do, but not from Julia currently
Actually we do, but I think primarily going the other direction: emitting GraphQL from Julia

elements.text: We do, but not from Julia currently
Actually we do, but I think primarily going the other direction: emitting GraphQL from Julia

text: yeah, our platform's API is GraphQL based (we use Hasura + Postgres to generate it - works great). So we're generally making client-side calls from Julia, so super excited to start seeing nice client-side utilities for GraphQL in Julia popping up :slightly_smiling_face:

elements.text: yeah, our platform's API is GraphQL based (we use Hasura + Postgres to generate it - works great). So we're generally making client-side calls from Julia, so super excited to start seeing nice client-side utilities for GraphQL in Julia popping up

text: Awesome, I evaluated Hasura but went with Postgraphile because we need onsite deployments... also Postgraphile is in TypeScript instead of Haskell which seemed way more approachable... but yeah I highly highly recommend code generation with GraphQL especially if you're changing the schema frequently!

elements.text: Awesome, I evaluated Hasura but went with Postgraphile because we need onsite deployments... also Postgraphile is in TypeScript instead of Haskell which seemed way more approachable... but yeah I highly highly recommend code generation with GraphQL especially if you're changing the schema frequently!

text: Another tool mentioned in the video is that you can use JET (<https://github.com/aviatesk/JET.jl>) to type-check the usage of the api response... so you get type safety on accessing data sent over network requests!
